definition:
Let $Q$ be a non-degenerate symmetric bilinear form over the real vector
space $\mathbb{R}^n$. A linear transformation $T\colon V \to V$ is said
to *preserve* $Q$ if $Q(Tx,Ty) = Q(x,y)$ for all vectors $x,y \in V$.
The subgroup of the general linear group $\operatorname{GL}(V)$
consisting of all linear transformations that preserve $Q$ is called the
*orthogonal group* with respect to $Q$, and denoted
$\operatorname{O}(n,Q)$.

If $Q$ is also positive definite (i.e., $Q$ is an inner product), then
$\operatorname{O}(n,Q)$ is equivalent to the group of invertible linear
transformations that preserve the standard inner product on
$\mathbb{R}^n$, and in this case the group $\operatorname{O}(n,Q)$ is
usually denoted $\operatorname{O}(n)$.

Elements of $\operatorname{O}(n)$ are called *orthogonal
transformations*. One can show that a linear transformation $T$ is an
orthogonal transformation if and only if $T^{-1} = T^{\operatorname{T}}$
(i.e., the inverse of $T$ equals the transpose of $T$).
